title: Finding your way in space
intro: What’s up and what’s down for astronauts who are floating in zero gravity? In space is there a true north, like here on Earth? And how is everything complicated by the fact that all the stars and planets are moving? Sam and Rob talk about it and teach you related vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: Who was the first person in space?
a)    Neil Armstrong b)    Yuri Gagarin c)    Valentina Tereshkova
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: use directions to go where you want to, often by using a map
instrument for finding directions that works using a magnetic needle that moves and always points north
point near the North Pole or South Pole where the Earth’s magnetic field is concentrated
decided randomly, not according to any particular reason or principle
unit measuring the distance that light travels in one year (around 6 trillion miles)
turn over or move into a different position

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Sam.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I’m Rob.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: How good are you at finding your way from A to B, Rob? Can you read a map?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Come on, Sam, this is the 21st century!  Everyone uses GPS and mobile phone apps to find their way around these days.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: True, but before mobile phones where invented arriving at your destination wasn’t so easy. At sea, sailors used the stars and Sun to navigate – to work out which direction they wanted to travel. And navigating on land was almost impossible without a compass – an instrument for finding directions that uses a magnetic needle which moves to always point north.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But, as we’ll be hearing in this programme, navigation at sea is easy compared to finding your way in outer space. After all, what’s up and what’s down for astronauts who are floating in zero gravity? In space is there a true north, like here on Earth? And how is everything complicated by the fact that all the stars and planets are moving?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Some big questions there, Rob, but first I have a question of my own. You asked how astronauts know which way is up, so who better to ask than the first person in space? But who was that? Was it: a)    Neil Armstrong? b)    Yuri Gagarin? or c)    Valentina Tereshkova?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, Neil Armstrong was the first man on the Moon, but I don’t think he was the first person in space. So I think it’s b) Yuri Gagarin.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: OK, I’ll reveal the answer later in the programme. Now let’s get back to Rob’s earlier question about whether there’s such a thing as north in space. And to answer that it’s first useful to know how north is found on Earth.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Listen as astrophysicist Ethan Siegal as he explains why a compass always points north to BBC World Service programme, CrowdScience.

transcript.author: Ethan Siegal
transcript.text: …because Earth behaves like it has a giant bar magnet in it, and your compass needle will point north towards Earth’s magnetic pole. And we’ve arbitrarily defined north as, that’s what we’re going to say ‘up’ is, like, the North Pole – that’s as ‘up’ as you can go.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Planet Earth is like a giant magnet. Because the needle of a compass is magnetised, it’s attracted to the magnetic pole – the points near the North and South Poles where the Earth’s magnetic field is concentrated.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: This explains how we find north, but Ethan points out that the decision to call north ‘up’ and south ‘down’ is arbitrary – decided by random chance, not based on any particular reason.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: When we look at a world map, we think of north as ‘up’, the USA in the northern hemisphere is above Brazil, in the southern hemisphere. But from space, Earth can just as easily be seen the other way up, with Australia, South Africa and South America at the top. Both views are equally true.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Wow, that’s a mind-blowing thought! But even though we can argue which direction is up, it’s still true that we can use a compass to navigate on Earth. However, this simply isn’t true in space. Here’s astrophysicist Ethan Siegal again to tell BBC World Service’s CrowdScience why:

transcript.author: Ethan Siegal
transcript.text: The problem with navigating in space is that the magnetic field flips irregularly every few hundred, or few thousand light years . There’s no central object like the black hole at the centre of our galaxy – it doesn’t dominate the whole galaxy, it doesn’t make a magnetic field that you can feel out here 25, 27-thousand light years from the centre. So, magnetism is not a good guide to navigating in space.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: A light year sounds like a measurement of time, but in fact it measures the distance that light travels in one year – which, given that light can travel 7.5 times around the Earth in one second , is a very, very long way - around 6 trillion miles, in fact.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, the problem is that every few hundred light years the magnetic field flips - turns over or moves into a different position. So, a compass, which depends on magnetism, is no good for navigating in space.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: So how do spacecraft know where they are, and which way to go? The answer is both simple and very clever – they use specialised heat sensors to detect the position of the Sun and use that to guide their way.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So simple yet so ingenious! I’m sure it would have impressed the first person in space, whoever they were.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Ah yes, in my question I asked who the first person in space was.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I said it was b) Yuri Gagarin. I’ve got to be right, haven’t I?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: It was right, of course! Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first man in space in 1961, with Valentina Tereshkova following in his footsteps to become the first woman in space two years later.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme on how to navigate – or find your way - in space.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: On Earth you can use a compass – an instrument with a magnetic needle that moves to point north, that is towards to the magnetic pole – a point near the North or South Poles where Earth’s magnetic field is strongest.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Saying that north is ‘up’ is arbitrary – done randomly, not according to any particular reason or principle.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: A light year is a unit measuring the distance that light travels in one year - around 6 trillion miles.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And finally, to flip means to turn over or move into a different position.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Once again, our time is up. Goodbye for now!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Bye bye!
